title: Quality Quotes #3
description: 2 quotes from ZaMM - Watch out for Blackbirds!

transcript_parts.text: hi there welcome to quality quotes in
which I read a quote from the work of
the great Robert in piercing and discuss
how its wisdom can help us live a better
life today I have two quotes from
chapter one of zen and the art of
motorcycle maintenance I've seen these
marshes a thousand times yet each time
they're new it's wrong to call them
benign you could just as well call them
cruel and senseless they are all of
those things but the reality of them
overwhelms half-way conceptions they're
a huge flock of red-winged blackbirds
ascends from nests in the cattails
startled by our sound anyone familiar

to realize that nature can be
represented in many ways two aspects of

so we survive if we did not understand
this aspect we would be Sol as they say
right now we see this aspect rapidly
multiplying across the globe and I think
sequestered in the artificial comfort of
technology we have forgotten that Mother
Nature will always be more powerful
George Carlin once said that
environmentalists who were so worried
about humans impact on the planet need
not worry because the planet will just

that reality is a dynamic changing
second to second experience and at any

and relish that raw emergence that may

by blackbirds there's a saying that you

underlying all of nature all of the

our perception and that's what counts
calmness then the dynamic unexpected and
that is what creates isn't that what

is a pattern so are you think about it
the second quote the Chautauqua's were
pushed aside by faster paced radio
movies and TV and it seems to me the
change was not entirely an improvement
perhaps because of these changes the
stream of national consciousness moves
faster now and is broader but it seems
to run less deep the old channels cannot
contain it and in its search for new
ones there seems to be growing havoc and
destruction along its banks this passage
written in the late 60s was a harbinger
of things to come
piercing a true visionary was able to
see this trend many years before
actually manifested in its entirety
now our national consciousness moves as
quickly as the coronavirus and we
respond just as reactively we have a lot

it is very superficial and now that
knowledge is so fragmented and with the
fragmentation comes havoc and
destruction you could call it the
meaning crisis so isn't it always better
to have more knowledge than a depth of
knowledge what's better quantity or
quality
well we actually know the answer to that
but what is the advantage of knowing
something deeply as opposed to knowing a
little about a lot of things the more
fragmented human knowledge becomes the
more we lose the connection we have with
the origins of that knowledge a cave
painting ends up as a brick in the
middle of a blank room at the Whitney
Art Museum somewhere along the way we
lose everything that led up to that
brick and just see the brick maybe it's
time to circle back around and see where
we lost our connection to those
mysterious mystical figures that connect
us with the gods with nature and with
each other and have for millennia the
Chautauqua
the edifying traveling talk of the 19th
century is something that is actually
being revived
thanks to TED talks and
long format interviews maybe you can
thank Joe Rogan for recapturing our
attention to remind us that it may be
time to slow down and really absorb
stuff how much more satisfying in

Hermann Hesse it was decided that
